title: What can I do with a food science degree? - Quora
tags: Jobs and Careers in Food Science

response.answer_text: You can work in quality control, quality assurance, product development, research and development, food safety, food security (different from safety in that you must find ways to assure a constant supply of food in areas where they are the regularly see famine). You can work in post-harvest storage, post-harvest drying. Also can work with minimizing food waste, and find ways to use the inevitable food waste. A food science degree makes you a scientists first and foremost - not a nutritionist, not an engineer, not a dietician. Consequently, any scientist position in a food industry is open to you. As you can see it does get quite diverse. But it will not allow you to design processes (that's for engineers), or be a major player in health concerns (reserved to nutritionists), nor will you be trained to help people with particular diets or weight loss plans (reserved for dieticians). However, you would be well suited to develop the latest greatest food product. To research a new way of measuring or processing food. Research technologies and methods for reducing food waste in poor countries. Many food scientists I know did a double major with nutrition. It is not necessary, but they felt it kept more doors open. I personally did not enjoy the nutrition aspects, but others love it. A double major is difficult, so choose wisely should you decide on that route.

Scope of Food Technologists in Industrial Sector: In a Small Scale Enterprise, a Food Technologist can become Technical Head.In a Medium Scale Enterprise, a Food Technologist can become Divisional head i.e. Production Head, QA Head or R&D head.In a Large Scale Enterprise, a Food Technologist can become Manager from Executive level of joining.Degree courses in advanced food technology, legal aspects, management etc, will give opportunity to grow even up to CEO level. Popular Sectors for Employment Food Manufacturing & Processing (Grains, fruits, vegetables, fish, meat etc.); Bakery & Confectionery Industry; Beverage Industry; Dairy Industry; Poultry Industry; Breweries; FMCG; Pharma-Biotech; Agro-Biotech; Food Supplements and Nutraceuticals; Healthcare; Academia & Research Institutes; Food Packaging Industry; Food Retail Popular Career Paths & Job Profiles in the Food Industry Research & Development (Food Scientist, Food Technologist, Food Chemist, Product Development Specialist)Quality Control & Assurance (Food Chemist, Food Inspector, Toxicologist)Food Processing (Food Processor, Process Development Specialist, Manufacturing Specialist, Food Production Manager)Sales, Marketing & Brand Management (various roles like other industries)Others (Dietician, Nutritionist, Animal Nutritionist, Diet & Fitness Counselor)For further details you may refer to: Ajit Singh Bhatnagar's answer to Is food technology a good career option?
